thread.title: Staff shortages in 96 German professions

author: news.com.au
title: Staff shortages in 96 German professions
text:
A STUDY has found that 96 German professions are unable to recruit the skilled staff they need, according to the Cologne Institute for Economic Research as cited in the Die Welt newspaper.
IT is most difficult to find staff in the health industry, according to the study that covered the period between August 2011 and April 2015.
There were three areas that suffered particularly badly over the period: science and technology jobs like mechatronics engineers and cutting machine operators; traditional skilled manual labour like sanitation, heating and air-conditioning; and healthcare workers. Some 20 professions in these areas are affected, with the vast majority of employees being women. The situation could be improved by converting part-time jobs to full-time "if the childcare infrastructure is expanded," the study recommended. More than five million people work in the bottle-necked professions, with one million of them working part-time, 670,000 in the health sector alone, the study said. The Nuremberg-based Institute for Employment Research (IAB) has predicted that, without immigration, the working population of Germany will drop from 45 million today to 37.5 million by 2030 and 29 million by 2050.
